channel.title: BBC News - Asia
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Amid violent reprisals, Afghans fear the Taliban's 'amnesty' was empty
item.description: Reports suggest the Taliban are searching for, and allegedly killing, people they pledged to leave in peace.

item.title: Female journalist who interviewed Taliban flees
item.description: Beheshta Arghand, who made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, has spoken out after fleeing the country.

item.title: India Covid: Economy sees record growth during deadly wave
item.description: The country suffered a devastating Covid spike in April and May but looser pandemic curbs still drove growth.

item.title: Tonga royals deny Australia horse trainer murder link
item.description: It has addressed tabloid allegations that the late king was involved in covering up a 1980s killing.

item.title: Air pollution may reduce life expectancy of Indians by nine years, says study
item.description: Millions in north India face the most extreme levels of air pollution in the world, the report says.

item.title: Japan finds black particles in Moderna vaccine
item.description: It comes less than a week after the country suspended more than a million doses due to contamination.

item.title: Covid: Sri Lanka in economic emergency as food prices soar
item.description: The government says it will seize food stocks and set prices to contain inflation.

item.title: Afghanistan: Last US military flight departs ending America's longest war
item.description: The US military's last C17 aircraft left Kabul with the ambassador on board early on Tuesday.

item.title: Afghanistan: US investigates civilian deaths in Kabul strike
item.description: Six children were among 10 killed in the strike which the US said was meant to stop a militant attack.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Toyota restarts driverless vehicles after accident
item.description: A visually impaired athlete from Japan's judo team was hit by one of the e-Palette pods on Thursday.

item.title: China cuts children's online gaming to one hour
item.description: Regulators are restricting game-playing for under 18s to an hour on Fridays, weekends and holidays

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Afghanistan athlete Hossain Rasouli makes debut after evacuation
item.description: Afghanistan evacuee Hossain Rasouli finally gets his chance to compete at the Tokyo Paralympics - and his opponents can't "help but feel joy".

item.title: Covid threatens Singapore's business hub crown
item.description: The South East Asian country faces opposing pressures over the large number of workers from overseas.

item.title: Afghanistan: Fleeing the Taliban into Pakistan and leaving dreams behind
item.description: The BBC speaks to Afghans fleeing the Taliban into Pakistan at the Chaman Spin Boldak border.

item.title: Fury as Covid crisis hits Australia's Aboriginal communities
item.description: Indigenous Australians say surging infections in remote areas should have been prevented.

item.title: Left behind in Afghanistan: If I can’t get out, I’ll die
item.description: An Afghan who had authorisation to fly to the UK speaks to the BBC about his struggle to escape.

item.title: The musicians who found ‘Instagram fame’ during the Covid-19 lockdown
item.description: With music venues shut due to Covid, many singers have taken to Instagram to connect with fans.

item.title: Possum skin cloaks: Reviving an Aboriginal cultural tradition
item.description: Indigenous people in south-east Australia are reviving an expression of cultural identity.

item.title: Afghanistan: Black Hawks and Humvees - military kit now with the Taliban
item.description: As the insurgents swept through Afghanistan they inherited an arsenal of US-made equipment.

item.title: In India, growing clamour to criminalise rape within marriage
item.description: An Indian court ruled that forced sex with a spouse is not rape. Campaigners say it's time for new laws.

item.title: Afghan music school falls silent under Taliban rule
item.description: As the new regime bans music, the head of Afghanistan's national music school says students are scared.
